channel.title: Interleaved RSS Feed
channel.description: This is an interleaved feed of the most recent entries from each RSS source, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: Pete McCloskey, Republican Who Tried to Unseat Nixon, Is Dead at 96
item.description: A liberal, antiwar California congressman, he had defeated Shirley Temple Black in a special election before launching a long-shot bid for the 1972 G.O.P. nomination.

item.title: In Serbia, Xi Underlines Close Ties With Ally That Shares Wariness of U.S.
item.description: Visiting friendly leaders in Eastern Europe, the Chinese president commemorated the 25th anniversary of a misdirected U.S. airstrike that destroyed China’s embassy in Belgrade.

item.title: How a NASM certification can kickstart your personal training career
item.description: As the need for fitness trainers and instructors grows, a NASM certification can be your entry point into a dynamic and in-demand field.

item.title: Workers Recall the Night Protesters Occupied Hamilton Hall
item.description: Maintenance workers had a firsthand view of how protesters seized the building, and wondered why the university failed to stop it.

item.title: U.S. Defense Chief Ties Biden’s Hold on Bombs for Israel to Rafah Offensive
item.description: Comments from Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III in a Senate hearing signaled the kind of leverage the United States can use to influence Israel’s conduct of the war in Gaza.

item.title: A 35-year-old junior Bank of America associate suddenly died—and it’s ignited discussions about Wall Street’s intense working conditions
item.description: Leo Lukenas III, a former Green Beret, joined Bank of America as an investment banker last summer. He died on May 2.

item.title: GM to Retire the Chevy Malibu to Make More EVs
item.description: The gasoline-powered Malibu was the last sedan sold by Chevrolet, the General Motors brand, in the United States.

item.title: Olympic Flame Arrives in Marseille
item.description: The flame will be carried on a 79-day journey across France and its territories, culminating in Paris with the start of the Olympic Games on July 26.

item.title: CEO Dara Khosrowshahi wants more workers to return to the office—preferably in an Uber
item.description: After a full year of profitability, Uber reported a first quarter loss and its CEO blames a lack of commuters post-pandemic.

item.title: In Serbia, Xi Underlines Close Ties With Ally That Shares Wariness of U.S.
item.description: Visiting friendly leaders in Eastern Europe, the Chinese president commemorated the 25th anniversary of a misdirected U.S. airstrike that destroyed China’s embassy in Belgrade.

item.title: What We Know About the Weapons the U.S. Sends to Israel
item.description: The United States accelerated weapons deliveries to Israel after the Oct. 7 Hamas-led attacks.

item.title: Panera is ditching its Charged Lemonade after 2 customers died—but Gen Z is still thirsting for dangerous snacks and drinks
item.description: A 30-ounce Charged Lemonade reportedly contained 390 milligrams of caffeine, the equivalent of about five Red Bulls.

item.title: RFK Jr. Says Doctors Found a Dead Worm in His Brain
item.description: The presidential candidate has faced previously undisclosed health issues, including a parasite that he said ate part of his brain.

item.title: Judy Devlin Hashman, Record-Holding Badminton Champion, Dies at 88
item.description: She won 10 singles titles at the prestigious all-England championships.

item.title: The UK’s second-richest man is demanding Manchester United workers return to the office—’If you don’t like it, please seek alternative employment’
item.description: Even if workers prefer flexibility, executives are getting impatient.
